title: Heartbreaking scene spotted by passing driver highlights worsening Aussie crisis
text:
The displacement of wildlife has become a 'national crisis', but little is being done to address it, animal rescuer Krysti Severi tells Yahoo News.

A poignant image of a dead kangaroo curled up on the grass in front of a housing development sign has some Aussies pondering if the heartbreaking scene was in fact staged. Tragically, the wildlife rescuer who desperately tried to save the animal seen in the viral photo confirmed to Yahoo News on Monday the brutal sight on the side of a busy road was in fact real.

"A gentleman driving past saw him trying to hide in the really small bit of shade cast from the sign," Krysti Severi said. "He was completely defeated and had given up. Temporary fencing surrounded him."

Krysti, who responds to wildlife calls in and around Melbourne every day, told Yahoo the impact of new developments on our native creatures is only getting worse, and despite the "nationwide crisis being in our face" like the photo indicates, little is being done to preserve animals.

"This issue is not just happening here, it's happening all across Australia. The developers and councils and government — they all aren't doing anything. No wildlife corridors are being erected. There's no safe areas for wildlife to escape.

ADVERTISEMENT

"It's heartbreaking — but it's actually pretty standard."

The kangaroo in question what spotted at Donnybrook, about 30km north of the city's CBD. Yahoo News has reached out to developer YourLand for comment.

"The roo was in extremely bad shape. He was struggling to breathe and struggling to move. He had a previous injury from being hit by a car, the area is notorious for being busy. There's a high volume of trucks and traffic going through there daily... we're at crisis point," Krysti said.

Krysti said there is a stark difference between how Aussies use kangaroo imagery and how we actually treat them. Source: Facebook/Rescue Rehabilitation Release

'Ironic' photos highlight poor treatment of kangaroos

It's not the first photo Krysti has taken that highlights the "ironic" difference between kangaroos being used as an Aussie emblem, and the reality of how they're actually treated.

She recently captured an image of a dead kangaroo lying at the side of the road while a Qantas play flew above it, proudly showcasing the outline of a kangaroo on its tail.

ADVERTISEMENT

Roos 'pushed' to breaking point by developments

Yahoo News has covered countless stories about kangaroos being misplaced from their habitat due to increased construction, from Sydney's west where housing development has significantly reduced the size of a once large mob, to Perth's northeast where roos were spotted looking disorientated on a makeshift road that was once their paddock.

Development is pushing kangaroos into more urbanised areas. Source: Vets for Compassion

The clearing of habitat pushes the native animals out of their land, and the increased traffic from development poses a significant risk, with vehicles travelling at speeds of 40km/h likely to cause fatalities if a collision occurs.

ADVERTISEMENT

Temporary fencing from developments often traps animals who are unable to find their way around it, while others may get injured trying to clear the fences. Their displacement also forces them into urban areas, with increased sightings of roos in shops and residential streets where off leash dogs can also pose risk.

"The odds are absolutely stacked against the animals," Krysti told Yahoo. "Developments are started and it pushes the roos further up. If it's not the development traffic, it's dogs off the leash or temporary fencing...kangaroos are being pushed and pushed away from their land."

title: Big change coming to hundreds of Woolworths stores to combat growing problem
text:
The Soft Plastics Taskforce was set up in the wake of the REDcycle collapse. Source: Woolworths/Facebook/Getty

Woolworths is aiming to significantly expand its in-store soft plastics collection trial over the next year, with plans to achieve "full coverage" across 500 stores within the next 12 months.

The supermarket giant claimed its biggest challenge in broadening the trial so far has been the fact there's not enough soft plastic recycling capacity in Australia to support nationwide collections.

But, speaking to Yahoo News, Woolworths said it will "work toward" increasing collection points from 120 stores currently, to about 500 across metropolitan Sydney, Melbourne, and in parts of southeast Queensland, the ACT and Adelaide in the coming months.

"The Soft Plastics Taskforce has now launched recycling trials in around 120 supermarkets, and has been careful not to exceed limited local recycling capacity as it works with the broader industry to responsibly rebuild the soft plastic recycling system," a spokesperson said.

ADVERTISEMENT

"We’re in close contact with soft plastic recyclers as they rebuild, and expand their operations, with a number of new recyclers starting to open their doors over the last year. The Taskforce was set up in the wake of the REDcycle collapse as an interim measure to facilitate an immediate response to the stockpiles left ... and [to] commence work on a new recycling scheme."

A "more permanent, industry-wide soft plastic stewardship program" is currently in the works to bring together all manufacturers and retailers who generate household soft plastics, the spokesperson added.

One of the key issues with recycling soft plastics is that they can only be recycled once or twice before their quality deteriorates, which limits their ability to be reused in the same form. Source: Facebook

What challenges face soft plastic recycling?

One of the key issues when it comes to recycling soft plastics is that they can only be recycled once or twice before their quality deteriorates, which limits their ability to be reused in the same form.

ADVERTISEMENT

Unlike rigid plastics that can be recycled more times, soft plastics, such as shopping bags, plastic wrap, and product packaging, degrade quickly during the recycling process.

It means they must be carefully managed and their recycling systems continually expanded to ensure the process remains sustainable. Soft plastic recycling remains vital for reducing landfill waste and supporting the circular economy.

Soft plastics account for a significant proportion of plastic waste in Australia — an estimated 538,000 tonnes annually, in fact — and without adequate recycling programs, these materials would often end up in landfills, contributing to environmental damage.

As the Taskforce continues to build a more robust recycling infrastructure, a more permanent and expansive soft plastic stewardship program is expected to play a crucial role in this effort, benefiting both the environment and the economy.

ADVERTISEMENT

The major supermarkets involved in the Soft Plastics Taskforce — Woolworths, Coles and Aldi — do not own or operate any soft plastic recycling facilities. Instead, independent third-party companies, with expertise in recycling, manage these operations.

The Taskforce works closely with these recyclers to expedite their development. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) has authorised the supermarkets to collaborate through the Taskforce, with the latest draft proposal extending this authorisation until July 31, 2026.

Recycling collection points in Woolworths supermarkets will reportedly return to the front of stores.
